reasoning: The critique targets a fairly important hinge in the essay’s “trade and compromise” optimism: the idea that preventing value-destroying threats is both crucial under moral uncertainty and (at least sometimes) achievable via stable institutions. If threat-prevention institutions can’t be made broadly acceptable in a pluralistic, low-WAM-convergence world, then the trade-based route looks significantly less promising. However, this point is not fully central to the essay’s overall position because (i) the authors already flag that it’s “not obvious” such a system would be mutually agreeable/stable and (ii) the essay’s broader conclusions include substantial pessimism/uncertainty even absent this issue. Strength is moderate: the argument plausibly pressures a key implicit inference (that robust anti-threat governance is implementable without collapsing into power struggles), but it doesn’t decisively refute the possibility of thinner, more widely endorsable “anti-extortion” norms or technical/architectural mitigations, and it partially reiterates concerns the essay already acknowledges. Most claims are broadly correct conceptually (anti-threat regimes typically require contested line-drawing and enforcement), though the critique somewhat overstates the inevitability that any effective regime must be seen as ideological domination. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Threat prevention regimes inevitably encode contested values and invite capture
